page.title: 10Home Life; Papa Westray
page.content: The day starts with the housewife lighting the coal fire in the cooker which also supplies the hot water. Breakfast is then prepared and the poultry fed while the menfolk attend to the cattle and general farm work. The housewife sets aside one day a week for washing and another for baking, mainly Bere Bannocks floury scones and cakes. The surplus is put into the deepfreeze. Dinner at 1pm consists of soup, main course and sweet, followed by tea or coffee. Some traditional courses are Salt Pork and Cabbage, and Salt Cuthes with melted butter or fat. Tea is at 5.30pm and consists of a cooked dish followed by home baking. The evenings are spent mending clothes and knitting, supper is a cup of tea and biscuits.
